{"uri": "2024-04-334535876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:58:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:58:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://roanoke.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/arizona-fake-electors-charges-2020-trump-election/article_2462b66f-1d97-5706-af4e-1ac0311634a8.html", "title": "Meadows, Giuliani among Trump allies charged in Arizona 2020 election probe", "body": "Ex-Trump White House lawyer Ty Cobb reacts to the Arizona indictment against the 11 fake electors and Trump allies over their efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss.\n\nPHOENIX -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\nRead more:\n\n0 Comments Tags Wire Dcc Lee-national\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "roanoke.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8095835458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:19:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:19:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/483969/Arizona-indicts-18-in-case-over-2020-election-in-Arizona-including-Giuliani-and-Meadows", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press FILE - Former Mayor of New York Rudy Giuliani speaks during a news conference outside the federal courthouse in Washington, Dec. 15, 2023. Guiliani, a lawyer for former President Donald Trump, was among those indicted Wednesday, April 24, 2024, in an Arizona election interference case.(AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana, File)\n\nAn Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8095963754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:48:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:48:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T03:47:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/arizona-indicts-18-in-election-interference-case-including-giuliani-and-meadows/article_c8c45e25-a1f2-5bba-a65b-70243f995120.html", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in election interference case, including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "FILE - Mark Meadows speaks with reporters at the White House, Oct. 21, 2020, in Washington. Meadows, chief of staff for former President Donald Trump, was among those indicted Wednesday, April 24, 2024, in an Arizona election interference case.\n\nPHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump 's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their roles in an attempt to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 election.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020. They include the former state party chair, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers, who are charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery.\n\nThe identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the documents. They were readily identifiable based on descriptions of the defendants, however.\n\nTrump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe indictment alludes to Giuliani as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud. Another defendant is referred to as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani.\n\nA lawyer for Eastman, Charles Burnham, said his client is innocent. Bobb did not respond to a text message seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was indicted in August in federal court over efforts to cling to power after his defeat, including the fake electors scheme. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his claim in that case that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nThe so-called fake electors facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.\n\nAssociated Press writers Gabe Stern and Scott Sonner in Las Vegas, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jonathan_j_cooper@eagletribune.com", "name": "Jonathan J. Cooper", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jacques_billeaud@eagletribune.com", "name": "Jacques Billeaud", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "josh_kelety@eagletribune.com", "dmoz/Society/Politics/Democracy", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Democracy", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/eagletribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/3e/23ec395a-de31-51c4-ac40-f20597721037/66299baf6d62d.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=1200%2C630&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-10-21", "textStart": 62, "textEnd": 75}, {"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 2754, "textEnd": 2767}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 6002, "textEnd": 6008}], "sentiment": -0.05882352941176472, "wgt": 226, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8095982829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:08:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:08:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:07:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://japannews.yomiuri.co.jp/news-services/ap/20240425-182297/", "title": "Arizona Indicts 18 in Case over 2020 Election in Arizona, Including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump 's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their roles in an attempt to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 election.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020. They include the former state party chair, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers, who are charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery.\n\nThe identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the documents. They were readily identifiable based on descriptions of the defendants, however.\n\nTrump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe indictment alludes to Giuliani as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud. Another defendant is referred to as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani.\n\nA lawyer for Eastman, Charles Burnham, said his client is innocent. Bobb did not respond to a text message seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was indicted in August in federal court over efforts to cling to power after his defeat, including the fake electors scheme. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his claim in that case that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nThe so-called fake electors facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "japannews.yomiuri.co.jp", "dataType": "news", "title": "japannews.yomiuri.co.jp"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-04-335515366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:30:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:30:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:14:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us/arizona-indicts-18-including-former-trump-lawyer-rudy-giuliani-in-election-interference-case", "title": "Arizona Indicts 18, Including Former Trump Lawyer Rudy Giuliani, in Election Interference Case", "body": "Former Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani is among the 18 people indicted in the Arizona election interference case. | Image:AP\n\nPhoenix: An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their roles in an attempt to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 election. The indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020.\n\nThey include the former state party chair, a 2022 US Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers, who are charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery.\n\nThe identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the documents. They were readily identifiable based on descriptions of the defendants, however.\n\nTrump an unindicted co-conspirator\n\nTrump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe indictment alludes to Giuliani as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud. Another defendant is referred to as Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani.\n\nA lawyer for Eastman, Charles Burnham, said his client is innocent. Bobb did not respond to a text message seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicised accusation and will be contested and defeated.\"\n\nGiuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponisation of our justice system.\"\n\nThe fake electors plot\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on December 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state.\n\nA one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, US District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was indicted in August in federal court over efforts to cling to power after his defeat, including the fake electors scheme. The US Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his claim in that case that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognised as duly elected, qualified electors.\n\nNo charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nThe so-called fake electors facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Senator Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organisation Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Senator Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the US Capitol during the January 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a US Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponising the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "2024-04-334638395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:04:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:04:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:23:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/04/24/arizona-indicts-18-in-election-interference-case-including-giuliani-and-meadows/", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in election interference case, including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "By JACQUES BILLEAUD, JONATHAN J. COOPER and JOSH KELETY (Associated Press)\n\nPHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump 's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their roles in an attempt to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 election.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020. They include the former state party chair, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers, who are charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery.\n\nThe identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the documents. They were readily identifiable based on descriptions of the defendants, however.\n\nTrump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe indictment alludes to Giuliani as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud. Another defendant is referred to as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani.\n\nA lawyer for Eastman, Charles Burnham, said his client is innocent. Bobb did not respond to a text message seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was indicted in August in federal court over efforts to cling to power after his defeat, including the fake electors scheme. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his claim in that case that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nThe so-called fake electors facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Gabe Stern and Scott Sonner in Las Vegas, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Trentonian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@trentonian.com", "name": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Campaigns_and_Elections", "label": "https://www.trentonian.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/Fake_Electors_Indictment_Arizona_90048.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 2584, "textEnd": 2597}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 5832, "textEnd": 5838}], "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-04-335037059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:35:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:35:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:46:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://myfox8.com/news/politics/us/giuliani-meadows-among-republicans-indicted-in-2020-arizona-fake-electors-case/", "title": "Giuliani, Meadows among 18 indicted in case over 2020 election in Arizona", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "myfox8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "myfox8.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 1132, "textEnd": 1145}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 4974, "textEnd": 4980}], "sentiment": -0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 224, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-04-334536282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:59:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:59:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:52:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/politics/arizona-mark-meadows-rudy-giuliani/2024/04/24/id/1162322/", "title": "Meadows, Giuliani Among Republicans Indicted in Arizona 'Fake Electors' Case", "body": "Former Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani are among those indicted in Arizona in the state's election interference case.\n\nAdditionally, 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud, and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe defendants include the former chair of the Arizona Republican Party, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate, and two sitting state legislators. The grand jury indictment also describes an unindicted co-conspirator who is clearly Trump.\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case, and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's attorney general in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-334605902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:12:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:12:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T02:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/arizona-fake-electors-charges-2020-trump-election/article_431e9e1a-0bbb-5c66-b7b1-e187f119a182.html", "title": "Meadows, Giuliani among Trump allies indicted in Arizona 2020 election probe", "body": "Ex-Trump White House lawyer Ty Cobb reacts to the Arizona indictment against the 11 fake electors and Trump allies over their efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss.\n\nPHOENIX -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump 's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their efforts to use so-called fake electors to try to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020, including the former state party chair, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers. They're charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery. The identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nTrump, who is described in the indictment as an unindicted co-conspirator, has argued that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his bid to avoid federal prosecution over his efforts to reverse his loss.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the document.\n\nOne is an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, which clearly describes Giuliani. Another is Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani. Eastman and Bobb did not respond to text messages seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nNational\n\nInvestigator says Trump, allies were uncharged co-conspirators in plot to overturn Michigan election\n\nBy ED WHITE - Associated Press\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.\n\nRead more:\n\nNational\n\nArizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows\n\nBy JACQUES BILLEAUD, JONATHAN J. COOPER and JOSH KELETY - Associated Press\n\n5 takeaways from the Jan. 6 report\n\n1. Eight chapters\n\n2. New details, pressures\n\n3. Behind the scenes\n\n4. Safeguarding democracy\n\n5. Record for history", "source": {"uri": "magicvalley.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Magic Valley"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_fake_electors_plot", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Trump fake electors plot"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "2020 United States presidential election"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 2890, "textEnd": 2903}, {"amb":
