{"uri": "8095849798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:38:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:38:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:38:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/partners/ap/national/arizona-indicts-18-in-case-over-2020-election-in-arizona-including-giuliani-and-meadows/article_2f9f9ec3-7c1d-56d2-a1c9-cb489d58f2b1.html", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "FILE - Mark Meadows speaks with reporters at the White House, Oct. 21, 2020, in Washington. Meadows, chief of staff for former President Donald Trump, was among those indicted Wednesday, April 24, 2024, in an Arizona election interference case.\n\nBy JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY - Associated Press\n\nPHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson NCHS placed on 'hold' Wednesday morning; students and staff safe Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\nAssociated Press writers Jonathan J. Cooper in Phoenix, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Wire Dcc Apmediaapi Arizona Fake Electors Charges 2020 Election Counterfeiting And Forgery Fraud Elections Politics Indictments U.s. {"uri": "8095766973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:53:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:53:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:52:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13347541/Arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-Republicans-falsely-declared-Trump-won-state-2020.html", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared...", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) - Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona\u00b4s Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden\u00b4s victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nFILE - Dr. Kelli Ward, left, chair of the Arizona Republican Party, talks with a supporter of President Donald Trump as they join the crowd at a rally outside the Arizona Capitol, Nov. 7, 2020, in Phoenix. Ward is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024 with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, File)\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan\u00b4s Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden\u00b4s victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states - Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin - to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state\u00b4s five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes\u00b4 predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes\u00b4 office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes\u00b4 office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP\u00b4s chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona\u00b4s 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages seeking comment that were left Wednesday with Jacob Hoffman, Kelli Ward, Michael Ward, James Lamon and Tyler Bowyer.\n\nAssociated Press writers Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.\n\nFILE - Republican Rep. Anthony Kern argues in support of a provision in the Arizona budget package that strips cash from Maricopa County Sheriff's Office, May 4, 2017, in Phoenix. Kern is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024, with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Bob Christie, File)\n\nFILE - Arizona Republican U.S. Senate candidate Jim Lamon poses for a photograph prior to the Arizona Republican Senate primary debate hosted by Newsmax at the Madison Center for The Arts, July 13, 2022, in Phoenix. Lemon is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, File)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_fake_electors_plot", "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/04/25/00/wire-84060275-1714002515-871_636x382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Phoenix, Arizona"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 386, "textEnd": 399}, {"amb": false, "date": "2020-11-07", "textStart": 1840, "textEnd": 1852}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 5014, "textEnd": 5020}, {"amb": false, "date": "2017-05-04", "textStart": 6104, {"uri": "2024-04-334516059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:14:46", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:14:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:05:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/news/national-news/ap-arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe defendants include the former chair of the Arizona Republican Party, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state legislators. The grand jury indictment also describes an unindicted co-conspirator who is clearly Trump.\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages seeking comment that were left Wednesday with the Wards, Hoffman, Lamon and Bowyer.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jonathan J. Cooper in Phoenix, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "wtaj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTAJ - www.wtaj.com"}, They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was also indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme.\n\nThe indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states - Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin - to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico attorney general Raul Torrez said that the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law.\n\nIn New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognised as duly elected, qualified electors.\n\nNo charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges.\n\nA grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are:\n\nKelli Ward, the state Republican Party's chair from 2019 until early 2023 State senator Jake Hoffman Tyler Bowyer, an executive of "https://img2.thejournal.ie/article/6363474/listing?version=6363476&width=590", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 808, "textEnd": 824}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 4703, "textEnd": 4712}], "sentiment": 0.08235294117647052, "wgt": 215, {"uri": "8095799274", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:30:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:30:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:30:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.wsfltv.com/Politics/political-scandals/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after they're served with the charges.\n\nJoe Biden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged his victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner. Days after that lawsuit was dismissed, they participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in Nevada, Michigan and Georgia.\n\nThe 11 people met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state in the 2020 election. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nPresident Biden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in Arizona, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner in the state.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave President Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending those results to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states. In December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans with felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results of the presidential election. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump could not persuade state officials to illegally swing the election in his favor, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate for Arizona's 8th Congressional District seat; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee during 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThis is a breaking news story. {"uri": "8095795261", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:25:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.sbsun.com/2024/04/24/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/", "title": "Ex-Chapman Law dean, Trump advisor John Eastman indicted by Arizona grand jury", "body": "John Eastman, a former dean of Chapman University's law school and an advisor to former President Donald Trump, was indicted by an Arizona grand jury for his role in trying to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.\n\nEleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the election also were indicted, as were six others who were not named.\n\nEastman's name was redacted from the indictment, as was former Trump advisor Rudy Giuliani's, but they are identifiable in the indictment.\n\nThey were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nTrump was not indicted but was referred to throughout the indictment as \"Unindicted Coconspirator 1.\"\n\nEastman was among seven who were indicted but had their names blacked out by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\nThe description of a defendant that matched Eastman read, in part, that the person \"was an attorney who encouraged the Republican electors to vote on December 14, 2020, and spread false claims of widespread election fraud. He also pressured the legislature in Arizona and six other states to change the outcome of the election. For example, on January 4, 2021, pushed then-Arizona Speaker of the House Rusty Bowers to convene a Special Session to decertify Arizona's presidential electors, telling him to 'just do it and let the court sort it out.'\"\n\nEastman has been quoted by Bowers as telling him that.\n\nEastman has raised more than $750,000 to help his legal defense on the site GiveSendGo.\n\nHe also casts himself as a victim of \"lawfare\" by an unhinged left, and complained that his bank accounts at Bank of America and USAA were closed without explanation. \"I strongly suspect that BofA's and USAA's decisions to cancel our accounts was a reflection of their increasingly \"woke\" corporate ideology against those who hold conservative political views or, as in my case, those who represented a client who is despised by our nation's ruling elite. If that is what is going on, it could be a big problem for them,\" he wrote on the site on April 23.\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages seeking comment that were left Wednesday with Jacob Hoffman, Kelli Ward, Michael Ward, James Lamon and Tyler Bowyer.\n\nStaff writers Teri Sforza and Todd Harmonson and the Associated Press {"uri": "8095764785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:50:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:50:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/04/24/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "Members of Arizona's Electoral College are sworn in prior to casting their votes Monday, Dec. 14, 2020, in Phoenix. Ross D. Franklin/Associated Press\n\nPHOENIX -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after they're served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged his victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner. Days after that lawsuit was dismissed, they participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in Nevada, Michigan and Georgia.\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state in the 2020 election. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in Arizona, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner in the state.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending those results to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states. In December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans with felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results of the presidential election. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump could not persuade state officials to illegally swing the election in his favor, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate for Arizona's 8th Congressional District seat; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee during 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nfiled under: Arizona, Donald Trump, President Biden Related Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Portland {"uri": "2024-04-334510069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:03:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:03:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:52:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://eu.yorkdispatch.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/04/24/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/73446298007/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "PHOENIX -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after they're served with the charges.\n\nMORE: What a TikTok ban in the US could mean for you\n\nMORE: Despite a number of hotly contested races, frontrunners dominated this week's primary election\n\nMORE: $10K damage done to at least 8 vehicles in Newberry Township vandalism: Police\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged his victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner. Days after that lawsuit was dismissed, they participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in Nevada, Michigan and Georgia.\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state in the 2020 election. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in Arizona, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner in the state.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending those results to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states. In December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans with felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results of the presidential election. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump could not persuade state officials to illegally swing the election in his favor, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate for Arizona's 8th Congressional District seat; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee during 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.", "source": {"uri": "yorkdispatch.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8095981986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:07:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:07:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:07:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/04/24/nation/arizona-indicts-18-election-interference-case-including-giuliani-meadows/", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in election interference case, including Giuliani and Meadows - The Boston Globe", "body": "The identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the documents. They were readily identifiable based on descriptions of the defendants, however.\n\nTrump himself was not charged but was referred to as an unindicted co-conspirator.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to spread lies about the last election that are echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic state Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe indictment alludes to Giuliani as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud. Another defendant is referred to as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani.\n\nA lawyer for Eastman, Charles Burnham, said his client is innocent. Bobb did not respond to a text message seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump was indicted in August in federal court over efforts to cling to power after his defeat, including the fake electors scheme. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his claim in that case that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nThe so-called fake electors facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-334549583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:27:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:27:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/arizona-case-2020-election-rudy-giuliani-mark-meadows-9289415/", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Rudy Giuliani and Mark Meadows", "body": "The Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the US Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a US Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8095927277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:09:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:09:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T03:09:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-04-25/arizona-indicts-republicans-donald-trump-election-fraud/103767788", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republican 'fake electors' who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "Eleven Republicans who had submitted a document to the United States Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election have been charged with conspiracy, fraud and forgery.\n\nThe charges make Arizona the fourth US state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe defendants include the former chair of the Arizona Republican Party, a 2022 US Senate candidate and two sitting state legislators.\n\nThe grand jury indictment also describes an unindicted co-conspirator who is clearly Mr Trump.\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on December 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state.\n\nA one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said their names will be released after they are served with the charges.\n\nOf the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Mr Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Mr Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Mr Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College.\n\nIn dismissing the case, US District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans signed the certificate.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges include former chair of Arizona republicans Kelli Ward, her husband Michael Ward, state Senator Jake Hoffman, youth organisation executive Tyler Bowyer and state Senator Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the US Capitol during the January 6 attack and is now a candidate for Congress.\n\nOthers charged include Greg Safsten, James Lamon, Robert Montgomery, Samuel Moorhead, Nancy Cottle and Loraine Pellegrino, all current or former party actives.\n\nNone responded when The Associated Press sought comment.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors have been charged in Georgia alongside Mr Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Mr Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nMr Trump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme.\n\nThe indictment states that when Mr Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Mr Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law.\n\nIn New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognised as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part {"uri": "8095817533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:57:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:57:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:57:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/arizona-fake-electors-charges-2020-trump-election/article_c499f8e7-2e9c-5104-9729-ed623eff8b79.html", "title": "Meadows, Giuliani among Trump allies charged in Arizona 2020 election probe", "body": "PHOENIX -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson NCHS placed on 'hold' Wednesday morning; students and staff safe Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\nRead more: National Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows By JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY - Associated Press 5 takeaways from the Jan. 6 report 1. Eight chapters 2. New details, pressures 3. Behind the scenes 4. Safeguarding democracy 5. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Arizona"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United
