{"uri": "8095786682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:14:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:14:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:14:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/04/24/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republican-fake-trump-electors/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republican fake Trump electors", "body": "The Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states\n\nBy Jacques Billeaud and Josh Kelety | Associated Press\n\nPHOENIX -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages {"uri": "8095857191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:47:57", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:47:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:47:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/arizona-indicts-18-for-2020-election-interference-including-rudy-giuliani/a994492193.html", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 for 2020 election interference including Rudy Giuliani", "body": "An Arizona grand jury has indicted Donald Trump's former chief of staff Mark Meadows, the ex-president's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani and 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released on Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election.\n\nIt shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nDemocratic attorney general Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office: \"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined.\"\n\nShe added: \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on December 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed that Mr Trump carried the state.\n\nA one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time.\n\nThe document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nMr Biden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Mr Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Mr Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Mr Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College.\n\nIn dismissing the case, US district judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case, and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims\".\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's attorney general filed felony charges in July against 16 Republican fake electors, including forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery. One defendant had the charges dropped after reaching a co-operation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Mr Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Mr Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nMr Trump was also indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Mr Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Mr Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico attorney general Raul Torrez said that the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors.\n\nNo charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mr Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mr Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mr Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges.\n\nA grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state Republican Party's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state senator Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organisation Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Senator Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the US Capitol during the January 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a US Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.", "source": President Trump is an unindicted co-conspirator\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans, including the attorney Boris Epshteyn, who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Mr. Trump defeated President Biden in Arizona in the last presidential election. It also features seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Mr. Giuliani. Another is described as Mr. Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Mr. Meadows.\n\nAttorney General Kris Mayes, a Democrat, said in a video statement \"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined. It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met at Phoenix on December 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Mr. Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party.\n\nThe document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored. Mr. Biden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Mr. Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Mr. Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, a district court judge, Diane Humetewa, said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing. The Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filings. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General, Dana Nessel, in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican \"alternate electors.\" One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Mr. Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in that state.\n\nMr. Trump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Mr. Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that his state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, alternate electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nNone of the 11 Arizona defendants responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jonathan J. Cooper in Phoenix, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "nysun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Sun"}, {"uri": "8095767293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:53:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:53:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/04/24/nation/arizona-indicts-republicans-fake-electors/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020 - The Boston Globe", "body": "Seven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after they're served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged his victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner. Days after that lawsuit was dismissed, they participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in Nevada, Michigan and Georgia.\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state in the 2020 election. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in Arizona, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner in the state.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending those results to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states. In December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans with felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results of the presidential election. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump could not persuade state officials to illegally swing the election in his favor, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate for Arizona's 8th Congressional District seat; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee during 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", {"uri": "2024-04-334505413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:52:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:52:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:24:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages seeking comment that were left Wednesday with Jacob Hoffman, Kelli Ward, Michael Ward, James Lamon and Tyler Bowyer.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "seattletimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Seattle Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8095762505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:47:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:47:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:47:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.baltimoresun.com/2024/04/24/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "By JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY (Associated Press)\n\nPHOENIX (AP) -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after those people are served with the charges.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nThere was no immediate response to phone messages seeking comment that were left Wednesday with Jacob Hoffman, Kelli Ward, Michael Ward, James Lamon and Tyler Bowyer.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in "https://www.baltimoresun.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/Fake_Electors_Indictment_Arizona_90048.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 442, "textEnd": 455}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 4500, "textEnd": 4506}], "sentiment": -0.0980392156862745, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8095764814", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:52:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:52:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:50:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/arizona-grand-jury-indicts-11-republicans-who-falsely-declared-trump-won-the-state-in-2020/article_15420575-89c1-5bb0-8644-ae3ddfe14044.html", "title": "Arizona grand jury indicts 11 Republicans who falsely declared Trump won the state in 2020", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- Eleven Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\"\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nSeven others were indicted, but their names were blacked out of records released by Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes. Her office said the names will be released after they're served with the charges.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged his victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner. Days after that lawsuit was dismissed, they participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in Nevada, Michigan and Georgia.\n\nThe eleven people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claimed Trump had carried the state in the 2020 election. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in Arizona, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner in the state.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending those results to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states. In December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans with felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results of the presidential election. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump could not persuade state officials to illegally swing the election in his favor, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said the state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate for Arizona's 8th Congressional District seat; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee during 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8095819861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:01:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:01:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:00:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/arizona-fake-electors-charges-2020-trump-election/article_b3bff37c-f5f8-5406-a8cc-421256a738ab.html", "title": "Meadows, Giuliani among Trump allies charged in Arizona 2020 election probe", "body": "JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY Associated Press\n\nPHOENIX -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nPeople are also reading... West Marion Inc. to restore and revitalize historic building McDowell Sheriff: Man shot, female suspect found with self-inflicted gunshot wound Victim, suspect in Monday shooting in Marion still hospitalized Man sentenced in fatal McDowell County wreck that killed couple Body of missing Asheville man found in Old Fort Old Fort receives $850,000 grant for streetscape project McDowell High wrestler Morgan Repasky signs with Montreat Raid of Marion home results in three arrested Ledbetters honored as Marion's Main Street Champions for 2023 Man charged with attempted murder in Deep Woods incident; 'Defendant is very dangerous,' court documents say 11-year-old dead in accidental shooting, Catawba County Sheriff's Office says MHS Roundup: Three hits from McKinney helps lift Lady Titans to victory McDowell County Schools Alumni Spotlight: Terry Wilson Public's help sought locating missing man in Dysartsville area Marion City Council OKs projects for South Garden, Ridge streets\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\nRead more: National Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows By JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY - Associated Press 5 takeaways from the Jan. 6 report 1. Eight chapters 2. New details, pressures 3. Behind the scenes 4. Safeguarding democracy 5. Record for history Tags Wire Dcc Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 2190, "textEnd": 2203}, {"amb": {"uri": "2024-04-334564807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:59:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:59:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:03:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/partners/ap/national/arizona-indicts-18-in-case-over-2020-election-in-arizona-including-giuliani-and-meadows/article_c6c8621d-5abe-5fd6-b1e7-4298bfec8d84.html", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "By JACQUES BILLEAUD and JOSH KELETY - Associated Press\n\nPHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nReactions mixed to Wentzville superintendent's $1 million buyout Former Wentzville schools superintendent gets more than $1 million in contract buyout St. Louis Zoo closed after 'intel' on Washington University carnival fights coming there Bally Sports owner banks on streaming TV growth, expects Amazon Prime deal by October Geno Auriemma says Dawn Staley's undefeated season was 'harder today' Holleman: She became a local celebrity during COVID. Now she's charged with two felonies. One person arrested after fights shut down Washington University student carnival St. Louis developer moves on Railway Exchange. New life for old Famous-Barr building? Hochman: The offense is awful. Cardinals have fewest HRs in NL, lowest average with RISP Neighbors worry about congestion from proposed Kingshighway apartments in St. Louis Missouri state senator berates secretary of state, calls him 'coward' -- and worse McClellan: Hamm, Coolidge and some questionable graduation speakers Hi-Pointe Drive-In and Taco Buddha form new restaurant group in St. Louis Boeing still feuding with critical Hazelwood supplier amid new fighter orders from Israel, US What Victor Scott II's option to minors means for rookie, center field job: Cardinals Extra\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\nAssociated Press writers Jonathan J. Cooper in Phoenix, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\n0 Comments Tags Wire Dcc Apmediaapi Arizona Fake Electors Charges 2020 Election Counterfeiting And Forgery Fraud Elections Politics Indictments U.s. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9510566", "eventUri": "eng-9510566", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2020-12-14", "textStart": 2455, "textEnd": 2468}, {"amb": {"uri": "8096380734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:00:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:00:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:59:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/apr/25/grand-jury-indicts-18-in-arizona-election-plot/", "title": "Grand jury indicts 18 in Arizona election plot", "body": "PHOENIX -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their efforts to use so-called fake electors to try to overturn Trump's loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Trump won Arizona in 2020, including the former state party chair, a 2022 U.S. Senate candidate and two sitting state lawmakers. They're charged with nine counts each of conspiracy, fraud and forgery. The identities of seven other defendants, including Giuliani and Meadows, were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\nTrump, who is described in the indictment as an unindicted co-conspirator, has argued that he can't be prosecuted for acts he committed while serving as president. The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday will hear arguments on his bid to avoid federal prosecution over his efforts to reverse his loss.\n\nWith the indictments, Arizona becomes the fourth state where allies of the former president have been charged with using false or unproven claims about voter fraud related to the election. Heading into a likely November rematch with Biden, Trump continues to make claims of fraud in the 2020 election echoed by many of his supporters.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the document.\n\nOne is an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread allegations of election fraud, which clearly describes Giuliani. Another is Trump's \"chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\nDescriptions of other unnamed defendants point to Mike Roman, who was Trump's director of Election Day operations; John Eastman, a lawyer who devised a strategy to try to persuade Congress not to certify the election; and Christina Bobb, a lawyer who worked with Giuliani. Eastman and Bobb did not respond to text messages seeking comment, nor did a lawyer who is representing Roman in a case in Georgia.\n\nGeorge Terwilliger, a lawyer representing Meadows, said he had not yet seen the indictment but if Meadows is named, \"it is a blatantly political and politicized accusation and will be contested and defeated.\" Giuliani's political adviser, Ted Goodman, decried what he called \"the continued weaponization of our justice system.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded innocent.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, past president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nIn a statement, Hoffman accused Mayes of weaponizing the attorney general's office in bringing the case but didn't directly comment on the indictment's allegations.\n\n\"Let me be unequivocal, I am innocent of any crime, I will vigorously defend myself, and I look forward to the day when I am vindicated of this naked political persecution by the judicial process,\" Hoffman said.\n\nNone of the others responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press seeking comment by deadline.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Jonathan J. Cooper, Kate Brumback and Marc Levy of The Associated Press.\n\nFILE - Mark Meadows speaks with reporters at the White House, Oct. 21, 2020, in Washington. Meadows, chief of staff for former President Donald Trump, was among those indicted Wednesday, April 24, 2024, in an Arizona election interference case. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)\n\nFILE - Dr. Kelli Ward, left, chair of the Arizona Republican Party, talks with a supporter of President Donald Trump as they join the crowd at a rally outside the Arizona Capitol, Nov. 7, 2020, in Phoenix. Ward is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024 with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, File)\n\nFILE - Republican Rep. Anthony Kern argues in support of a provision in the Arizona budget package that strips cash from Maricopa County Sheriff's Office, May 4, 2017, in Phoenix. Kern is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024, with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Bob Christie, File)\n\nFILE - Arizona Republican U.S. Senate candidate Jim Lamon poses for a photograph prior to the Arizona Republican Senate primary debate hosted by Newsmax at the Madison Center for The Arts, July 13, 2022, in Phoenix. Lemon, one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election, was charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024, with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, File)\n\nFILE - Arizona Rep. Jake Hoffman, R-Queen Creek, is sworn in during the opening of the Legislature at the state Capitol, Jan. 11, 2021, in Phoenix. Hoffman is one of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024, with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, Pool, File)\n\nFILE - Kelli Ward, with her husband Michael Ward at her side, concedes to Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., in the race for the Republican nomination to U.S. Senate, Aug. 30, 2016, at her primary night party at a hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz. Ward and her husband are two of 11 Republicans in Arizona who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring Donald Trump had beaten Joe Biden in the state during the 2020 presidential election were charged Wednesday, April 24, 2024, with conspiracy, fraud and forgery, marking the fourth state to bring charges against \"fake electors.\" (David Kadlubowski/The Arizona Republic via AP, File)", {"uri": "8095814532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:53:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:53:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:52:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/arizona-indicts-18-in-case-over-2020-election-in-arizona-including-giuliani-and-meadows/article_15420575-89c1-5bb0-8644-ae3ddfe14044.html", "title": "Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows", "body": "PHOENIX (AP) -- An Arizona grand jury has indicted former Donald Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and lawyer Rudy Giuliani along with 16 others in an election interference case.\n\nThe indictment released Wednesday names 11 Republicans who submitted a document to Congress falsely declaring that Donald Trump beat Joe Biden in Arizona in the 2020 presidential election. It shows seven other defendants whose names were not immediately released because they had not yet been served with the charges.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe Associated Press was able to determine the identities of the unnamed defendants based on their descriptions in the indictment.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOne is described as an attorney \"who was often identified as the Mayor\" and spread false allegations of election fraud, a description that clearly describes Giuliani. Another is described as Trump's \" chief of staff in 2020,\" which describes Meadows.\n\n\"I will not allow American democracy to be undermined,\" Democratic Attorney General Kris Mayes said in a video released by her office. \"It's too important.\"\n\nThe 11 people who had been nominated to be Arizona's Republican electors met in Phoenix on Dec. 14, 2020, to sign a certificate saying they were \"duly elected and qualified\" electors and claiming that Trump carried the state. A one-minute video of the signing ceremony was posted on social media by the Arizona Republican Party at the time. The document was later sent to Congress and the National Archives, where it was ignored.\n\nBiden won Arizona by more than 10,000 votes. Of the eight lawsuits that unsuccessfully challenged Biden's victory in the state, one was filed by the 11 Republicans who would later sign the certificate declaring Trump as the winner.\n\nTheir lawsuit asked a judge to de-certify the results that gave Biden his victory in Arizona and block the state from sending them to the Electoral College. In dismissing the case, U.S. District Judge Diane Humetewa said the Republicans lacked legal standing, waited too long to bring their case and \"failed to provide the court with factual support for their extraordinary claims.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDays after that lawsuit was dismissed, the 11 Republicans participated in the certificate signing.\n\nThe Arizona charges come after a string of indictments against fake electors in other states.\n\nIn December, a Nevada grand jury indicted six Republicans on felony charges of offering a false instrument for filing and uttering a forged instrument in connection with false election certificates. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nMichigan's Attorney General in July filed felony charges that included forgery and conspiracy to commit election forgery against 16 Republican fake electors. One had charges dropped after reaching a cooperation deal, and the 15 remaining defendants have pleaded not guilty.\n\nThree fake electors also have been charged in Georgia alongside Trump and others in a sweeping indictment accusing them of participating in a wide-ranging scheme to illegally overturn the results. They have pleaded not guilty.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn Wisconsin, 10 Republicans who posed as electors settled a civil lawsuit, admitting their actions were part of an effort to overturn Biden's victory. There is no known criminal investigation in Wisconsin.\n\nTrump also was indicted in August in federal court over the fake electors scheme. The indictment states that when Trump was unable to persuade state officials to illegally swing the election, he and his Republican allies began recruiting a slate of fake electors in battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- to sign certificates falsely stating he, not Biden, had won their states.\n\nIn early January, New Mexico Attorney General Ra\u00fal Torrez said that state's five Republican electors cannot be prosecuted under the current law. In New Mexico and Pennsylvania, fake electors added a caveat saying the election certificate was submitted in case they were later recognized as duly elected, qualified electors. No charges have been filed in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn Arizona, Mayes' predecessor, Republican Mark Brnovich, conducted an investigation of the 2020 election, but the fake elector allegations were not part of that examination, according to Mayes' office.\n\nIn another election-related case brought by Mayes' office, two Republican officials in a rural Arizona county who delayed canvassing the 2022 general election results face felony charges. A grand jury indicted Cochise County Supervisors Peggy Judd and Tom Crosby in November on one count each of conspiracy and interference with an election officer. Both pleaded not guilty.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Republicans facing charges are Kelli Ward, the state GOP's chair from 2019 until early 2023; state Sen. Jake Hoffman; Tyler Bowyer, an executive of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA who serves on the Republican National Committee; state Sen. Anthony Kern, who was photographed in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack and is now a candidate in Arizona's 8th Congressional District; Greg Safsten, a former executive director of the Arizona Republican Party; energy industry executive James Lamon, who lost a 2022 Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat; Robert Montgomery, chairman of the Cochise County Republican Committee in 2020; Samuel Moorhead, a Republican precinct committee member in Gila County; Nancy Cottle, who in 2020 was the first vice president of the Arizona Federation of Republican Women; Loraine Pellegrino, president of the Ahwatukee Republican Women; and Michael Ward, an osteopathic physician who is married to Kelli Ward.\n\nNone of the 11 responded to either phone, email or social media messages from The Associated Press on Wednesday seeking comment.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jonathan J. Cooper in Phoenix, Kate Brumback in Atlanta and Marc Levy in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"},
